Wilayah di Kepulauan Sumenep Masih Kekurangan Air Bersih
05 Nov 2019, 17:42 by , https://www.facebook.com/CNNIndonesia


KRI Teluk Ende-517 yang membawa Satgas Penanggulangan Bencana Kekeringan tiba di Sumenep. (Dok. Pemprov Jatim)

Jakarta, CNN Indonesia -- Masyarakat Sumenep, Jawa Timur masih mengalami krisis air bersih meski hujan sudah mulai turun. Bahkan hingga kini beberapa daerah di wilayah Kepulauan Sumenep masih terdampak kekeringan. Dandim 0827/Sumenep Letkol Inf Ato Sudiatna membenarkan fenomena tersebut. "Memang benar ada beberapa desa di wilayah kepulauan Sumenep yang mengalami kekurangan air bersih. Rencananya Selasa 5 November ada penyerahan bantuan air bersih dari Ibu Gubernur Khofifah didampingi Panglima Koarmada II Laksda TNI Heru Kusmanto," ujar Letkol Sudiatna melalui keterangannya, Senin (4/11). Ia menjelaskan, selama musim kemarau warga di wilayah kepulauan masih mengandalkan air dari beberapa sumber yang ada. "Ada beberapa sumber air tapi debitnya kecil dan warga harus beli," terangnya.Terkait hal tersebut, Gubernur Jawa Timur lantas menyerahkan bantuan persediaan air bersih bagi warga di kepulauan. Bantuan yang diberikan sebanyak 3.000 hingga 5.000 jeriken air bersih diangkut oleh KRI Teluk Ende-517. Usai kapal dari jajaran Satuan Amfibi Koarmada II itu bersandar, bantuan air bersih langsung diturunkan untuk segera didistribusikan. "Para Babinsa di kepulauan sudah cek lokasi dan siap bantu. Hari ini juga saya pantau langsung di lokasi Pulau Sapudi," ujarnya. Setelah seremoni di kantor Kecamatan Gayam di Pulau Sapudi, distribusi dengan menggunakan kapal TNI AL akan bergeser ke beberapa pulau lain. Tercatat tiga pulau menjadi sasaran pemberian bantuan air bersih yakni Pulau Sapudi meliputi Kecamatan Gayam dan Nonggunong. Kemudian Pulau Giligenting meliputi Kecamatan Giligenting dan Pulau Kangean meliputi Kecamatan Arjasa dan Kangayan. "Semoga proses distribusi bantuan bisa berjalan lancar. Di lokasi, para Babinsa juga sudah membantu koordinasi dengan warga setempat," pungkasnya.

Areas in the Sumenep Islands Still Short of Clean Water
05 Nov 2019, 17:42 by, https://www.facebook.com/CNNIndonesia


KRI Teluk Ende-517 that brought the Drought Disaster Management Task Force arrived in Sumenep. (Doc. Of East Java Provincial Government)

Jakarta, CNN Indonesia - The people of Sumenep, East Java are still experiencing a clean water crisis even though rain has started to fall. Even today some areas in the Sumenep Islands region are still affected by drought. Dandim 0827 / Sumenep Lt. Col. Inf Ato Sudiatna confirmed this phenomenon. "It is true that there are several villages in the Sumenep archipelago that are experiencing shortages of clean water. The plan is Tuesday, November 5, there will be a delivery of clean water from Mrs. Governor Khofifah accompanied by Commander of the Armed Forces Commander II Rear Admiral Heru Kusmanto," Lieutenant Colonel Sudiatna said in his statement on Monday (4/11) ). He explained, during the dry season residents in the island region still rely on water from several existing sources. "There are several sources of water but the debit is small and residents must buy it," he explained. Related to this, the Governor of East Java then handed over clean water supply assistance to residents in the islands. Aid provided as much as 3,000 to 5,000 jerry cans of clean water were transported by KRI Teluk Ende-517. After the ship from the Amphibi Koarmada II Unit leaned back, clean water assistance was immediately sent down to be distributed immediately. "The Babinsa in the islands have checked their locations and are ready to help. Today I will also monitor directly on the location of Sapudi Island," he said. After the ceremony at the Gayam District office on Sapudi Island, distribution using Indonesian Navy ships will shift to several other islands. Three islands were recorded as targets for clean water assistance, namely Sapudi Island, covering the Districts of Gayam and Nonggunong. Then Giligenting Island covers Giligenting District and Kangean Island covers Arjasa and Kangayan Districts. "Hopefully the aid distribution process can run smoothly. At the location, the Babinsa have also helped coordinate with local residents," he concluded.
